transport.comment:
That depends on who you're talking about.  There are folks in Southern California who commute 60 miles each way.  Yes, I think they're crazy, too, but they do it.  A long time to top up their vehicle literally doubles their commute time.

And I'll take it you've never had to go on any sort of road trip where you're trying to get somewhere.  It's been three times that I made the trip between Seattle and San Diego.  That's 20 hours of driving time, plus about 45 minutes refueling time.  Hydrogen promises comparable time.  Even with a Tesla, using their superchargers, that top up time becomes about 3 hours.

So, for the average person, on the average trip, no, top-up time doesn't matter a lick.  When it *does* matter, though, it's *killer*

transport.comment:
Not OP, but there are a couple important points in there.

> The core of the reliability ratings from Consumer Reports were based on early model drivetrain units that needed replacing. Those drivetrain issues were fixed (for free) and the problem has been addressed and hasn't been a common problem for new Teslas for literally a couple of years now...and they've increased the drivetrain warranty to 8 years/unlimited miles to back it up.

The problem is that [the reliability statistics aren't significantly improving.](http://www.truedelta.com/Tesla-Model-S/reliability-1095)

>Surely you have some sort of source for average Tesla repair costs to back this up?

I don't have overall averages, but to be blunt, shit ain't cheap.

* $6000 for a touchscreen replacement
* $2000 per axle for air suspension replacement
* $1200 per handle for door handle replacement

[Source.](http://www.greencarreports.com/news/1100226_life-with-tesla-model-s-should-i-buy-the-extended-warranty/page-2)

Posted labor rates for Tesla service centers are $150-$175 an hour, which will seriously drive up any sort of repair or maintenance.

[Source.](https://teslamotorsclub.com/tmc/threads/ill-need-that-service-agreement.14739/)

Body repairs are [known to be expensive as well.](http://gas2.org/2015/01/06/this-is-what-30000-of-damage-looks-like-on-a-tesla-model-s/)

>Again - do you have a source that this is even a moderately common problem for Tesla owners in general?

People have had to wait [3+ weeks for critical issues](http://gas2.org/2016/05/21/2012-tesla-model-s-needs-8500-brake-repair/), I don't want to know how long the wait would be for something less critical than the brakes.  Granted that's a specific case and not an overall average, but in what scenario is it okay for a customer to have to wait three weeks to get a serious brake issue fixed?

transport.comment:
For ICE vehicles, automakers outsourced production of nearly everything except the engine and drivetrain.  They felt this important IP, and would determine the industry winners.

They didn't care who made the windows, steering wheels, etc.  Many OEMs bought from the same undifferentiated suppliers.  They just wanted it cheap.  Remember when Tata had airbag problems? There were recalls from a half dozen OEMs because so many used Tata.

The problem with the Bolt is that GM is now not making any "important" parts.  Their only job is assembly and branding.  They don't build any of the engine/motor/battery/drivetrain. The company is getting hollowed out when looking toward the future.

This is a recipe for disaster, as they don't have any expertise in the critical parts of the EV.  If/when the market swings toward EVs, they'll have no competitive advantage.  I predict they'll really struggle.  What good is ICE expertise in an EV world?  

It'll be like Kodak all over again.

transport.comment:
> Not what I was saying.

It doesn't matter if you were saying it or not; the reality is that selling the cars for anything less than twice the price of what a top-spec loaded Corvette went for at the time, GM would lose a fuckton of money on each car. 

Tesla is building the world's largest battery factory (and full credit to them for that), and that factory is expected to lower prices by 30% after five years, and that's by the most optimistic estimates.  So suppose GM had put in an equivalent investment back in the 90s.  Oh good, now their $100,000 two seater can sell for $70,000, still an order of magnitude above what any consumer would come close to paying. And that's after eating five years worth of losses.

People need to come to grips with the fact that there was no conspiracy, and maybe, just maybe, the technology wasn't CLOSE to being viable in the 90s, and that no push from any single company would have changed that.

transport.comment:
You need to look at the pack as a whole, typical batteries 1C is acceptable, my Volt lets the batteries peak at 8.5C, so higher is certainly possible. I have 50C capable RC car batteries.

Anyways, this means that a vehicle with a 60mi range at 60mph would thus discharge it's battery at 1C, from that it's abundantly clear that a vehicle with a 120mi range is going to have a battery that is usually operating under 0.5C. If you look at other vehicles out there it's very clear that anything with a 100\+mi range has zero problems getting power out of those batteries, in fact if you look at real world EVs in that class, they all blow the socks off every other car in their class in terms of power to the wheels. This is because the batteries for 100\+mi range produce about as much power as the vehicle can ever dream of using in normal traffic.

And the 2020 Roadster is no exception, build an EV for 600mi\+ range, and you find out you have so much available power you're calling up tire manufacturers for help because you'll melt any normal tire.

The BYD buses are having problems because they went cheap everywhere, it's a "almost 100mi" bus, not 100mi\+, and they are trying to operate them on routes that at near their limits. They could have easily paid for a 200mi bus, cell size is irrelevant, just install two of whatever packs they have and double up the motors. It's purely a cost issue, and BYD is a company that knows to to build cheap stuff.

transport.comment:
I'll add my anecdote about mobile service. 

We picked up our MYP with a large visible scratch on the spoiler ($800 carbon fiber spoiler...). We mentioned it to the delivery guy, and he immediately went ahead and scheduled mobile service to simply replace it - free since it's a delivery defect. It honestly wasn't that big of a deal, but hey if it's free and it's mobile service, why not. 

Well, let's just say it took over a month and numerous reschedules before the guy finally showed up at our house. He was originally supposed to show up at my work place where I intentionally parked the car outside that day. But after even more delays and fumbling that day, he ended up just showing up at our house since it was after business hours and he wasn't sure when he'd make it - therefore, I just went home. 

Anyway, guy was nice enough and we had a nice chat about our other car (Ioniq 5 - guy used to be a Hyundai tech). He moves on to finally replace the spoiler. 

We now have a scratch free spoiler. That's just straight up loose. The looseness was not an issue on the old spoiler. I honestly would have preferred to keep a non-loose spoiler with a scratch than this one. I don't even feel like going through the process to schedule mobile service again, and just deal with the loose spoiler. From looking around online, this is a common problem with the spoiler. When it eventually just falls off, I'm going to live without this ridiculous spoiler.

transport.comment:
>The OIG "identified several clear benefits of adopting electric vehicles into the postal delivery fleet, including improved sustainability and environmental impacts," the document continues. "Electric vehicles are generally more mechanically reliable than gas-powered vehicles and would require less maintenance. Energy costs will be lower for electric vehicles, as using electricity to power an electric vehicle is cheaper than using gasoline."

BEVs aren't all sunshine and rainbows for this use case... although these are the types of vehicles we want to electrify because they'd use the lion's share of their capacity daily to reduce emissions.  Some issues:

* First... to a large degree these days, the post office is essentially paying people to dig holes.  They employ their own mechanics, so reliability isn't exactly a good thing if the goal is to keep people employed.
* Gas savings will be offset by battery expense to a degree.
* 200,000k+ vehicles at 30-40 kWh per vehicle on average is 6-8 GWh of cells, and it's 'mostly' a one time purchase.  Not very likely these are getting a volume discount.
* Batteries could be cycled daily.  A pack with 2000 cycles being cycled daily 6 days per week may only last 6.5 years.
* Winter.  A 30 kWh battery in a mail truck that's in use 8 hours per day with the heater running the entire time could use 2+ kW per hour.  That's 16 kWh per day.  A 40 kWh battery would have 24 kWh remaining for driving, while a 30 kWh battery would have 14 kWh remaining.
* Battery degradation could reduce range over time.
* Charging.  Do you install DCFCs and rotate the cars nightly, or do you install plugs in the lots?  Those lots are rarely ever organized.  How much electrical work does each lot need to provide this boost in energy?  It may not be as simple as running new electrical lines to the parking spots, but installing new and expensive service at the post office.

&#x200B;

>The document also emphasizes that despite the higher upfront cost of buying new EVs and installing charging infrastructure, "the adoption of electric delivery vehicles could save the Postal Service money in the long term," particularly for longer routes that are up to 70 miles, because the USPS would save on rapidly rising gas costs.

Are gas prices rapidly rising?  They've certainly spiked, but spikes are often temporary; as can be seen in literally every instance of it happening in the past.  They may last a year or two before receding.  Now a proper emissions tax would be a different story.

&#x200B;

>The outlet also noted that "postal management said it could fully electrify its fleet with an injection of $6.9 billion: $3 billion for the higher vehicle cost and $3.9 billion for the chargers. If such funding were provided, the IG said the lifetime cost of EVs would be 11% lower than gas vehicles. It added that USPS may be eligible for local incentives as well."

Ah yes, they're always possible...IF...they're subsidized.  Subsidies aren't free.  We taxpayers pay for them, and an additional $6.9 billion is a lot of money.

&#x200B;

==========================================

If we are to electrify mail trucks, we should concentrate on electrifying them in regions with the most clean energy first, and the states should be responsible for the subsidies.  Why should someone in Michigan subsidize a mail truck in California; the wealthiest state in the nation, while California reaps the rewards of the lower mail truck fuel prices?

housing.comment:
When I do freelance project work, I primarily target small and mid-sized commercial solar installations. 

If you can't sell the client an array within an acceptable payback period, or you can't give them a solid financing option, then you're chasing windmills - regardless of the existence of the tax credit. The tax credit determines how large a system the client can accommodate in a profitable manner. 

Solar power is less than 1% of the USA electric grid. Rather than try to solve the problem of "my business wants solar but leases the building", I prefer to target the lower hanging fruit. Businesses who own their own building >> 1% of USA electric use, so why bother even asking that question at this point in time?

housing.comment:
~~For SolarCity, isn't there a monthly payment for leasing the panels in addition to the cost per kWh? It's very important you take that into account.~~ Also, you use a LOT of electricity. How big is your house? Mine is 1200 sqft, build in 1920 and I have never used more than 600kWh in one month. My average is around 350kWhm. I can't imagine spending $400 in one month for electricity.

Also, if you were to buy a 2.6kW system at the same price as what I got my system for, it would cost about $5000 after all the tax credits. Given the data above, it seems like you pay $2800/year on electricity. At 15% offset, that's a savings of $420/year on your bill. You also get around $200/MWh generated through SRECs, so your total savings is close to $620/year, giving you an expected payoff period of 8 years.

I think given your incredible electricity usage, it's best to get a [free energy audit](http://www.masssave.com/) and see how you can reduce it.

Edit: There's a PPA option and a leasing option for SolarCity, I got them confused. Either way, I don't think you're getting a good deal.

housing.comment:
Good.

> The cost of electricity from large-scale solar installations now is comparable to and sometimes cheaper than natural gas-fired power,

Rooftop solar doesn't make sense without government subsidies for most people, in most places.

Large ground mount solar is cheaper, and can feed into the existing power grid such that the grid isn't being asked to do two-way duty on a grid designed for centralized production.  Plus, the power company can monitor a central field much more easily and ramp the turbines ahead of time if a large front is going through or something.

housing.comment: I recently bought a home in CT with solar panels already installed. I had no choice in taking the system over because the homeowner leased the panels. Facing this during buying the house I contacted the original installer and discovered some serious hidden costs. I thought this is worth mentioning because I've never seen this mention here. One, is the cost of replacing your inverter every 7 years or so at approx $1500. I was told by the installer that they last about 7 years before they fail or become inefficient enough to replace.  Two, is the cost associated with any roof repair. Anything not covered under your homeowners insurance will cost you. My roof will reach end of life only about 10-12 years into the Solar system term. So the panels will have to be removed and replaced at an approx cost of $4000 on top of the roof expense. Third is any service/maintenance/cleaning you can't do yourself will also cost you approx $350 each time the installer makes a house call. These are all quoted prices directly from the original installer of the system. None of these costs were listed anywhere in their literature, brochures or original proposals to the homeowner.  This is just a heads up that there are potential hidden costs not associated with the general TCO discussion of solar panels. Fyi, I negotiated the price of the home down because of these costs. So not sure were everyone gets the idea that solar panels increase a homes value?

>A 2013 survey of new EV owners in California, which represents
more than 40 percent of the market for EVs, found that
32 percent of respondents had solar photovoltaic (PV) systems
in their homes.

The 'as much as' weasel words are what got me to actually look at your sources, and they don't really say what you claim. Assuming the survey was done properly, there still isn't any info about the size of the systems, whether the EV owners charge while their systems are producing energy, whether they have battery systems to capture energy for usage later, etc.

You might say that net metering evens things out, but [this page](http://www.gosolarcalifornia.ca.gov/solar_basics/net_metering.php) on ca.gov seems to claim that that's only available for 1kW systems and below, which is paltry for EV charging needs.

Overall, I liked the video, but please be more careful with your claims in the future. It always pisses me off when people can find inaccuracies with a single claim in a video like this, then use it as an excuse to claim that everything else in the video is BS/a conspiracy/whatever else nincompoopery you find online. housing.comment:
>what? AC coupling is rare...

I'm not in disagreement that AC coupling is rare. Hence the comments about *the future*. 

> Most AC coupled systems ARE interconnected...DC bimodals are more likely not interconnected.

You're proving my point. In 5-10 years, most residential battery systems will be interconnected. I believe they will be continue to be AC-coupled, as it is a more efficient solution for grid-tied systems, when backfeeding the grid or pursuing a grid-assist design philosophy. 

> "Therefore, the solar array is never interconnected" - This has nothing to do with AC vs DC coupling.

When approaching a grid-assist design, you need fewer BOS components with AC-coupling vs. DC coupling. It's already obvious to utilities that AC-coupling is the most cost-effective solution for grid-connected arrays. However, it seems to me that utility policies (especially under Trump) are going to become alot more anti-solar, which will force customers to seek out the grid-assist design philosophy. Obviously in solar friendly territories, grid-interconnection will still be the preferred option. But it doesn't matter because AC-coupling is still the most efficient solution for grid-interconnected design.

DC-coupling is only more efficient than AC-coupling when you are primarily running off of your battery bank, such as an 100% off-grid home.

Here's a transcript:

> (voiceover by interviewer with imagery of natural disasters and melting ice) Over the last 10 years, sea levels have risen at an alarming rate, biodiversity is reportedly declining faster than that of any time in human history, and millions--millions-- of people have been affected by extreme weather, like hurricanes and floods. As 2019 ends, this year is likely to be one of the hottest on record, so what can we expect over the next decade? CBS News meteorologist and climate climate specialist Jeff Veradeli(?) is here to explain

> interviewer: How are you this morning?

> Jeff: I'm doing great!

> Interviewer: I know when we hear climate change, we do think doom and gloom, the world's coming to an end relatively quickly, but what are some of the technological advancements and innovations we should be looking at to help improve the issue of climate change? 

> Jeff: So this is the best part--sometimes you go to the doctor and the doctor says "I'm sorry, there's not much I can do for you." We *know* the answer, and the answer is the move away from fossil fuels and to start leaning on sustainable energy--and here's the best part: The more we use sustainable energy--which is this energy that's given to us by the sun and the wind; it is free--the more that the prices go down of that, the more that we have to create vast industries and vast employment and opportunities for ourselves, so the bottom line is that we can create a better life for ourselves! So we don't have to look at this as a death sentence for doom and gloom, we can look at this as a time that we can create a brand new and better future with better jobs (higher paying jobs)--just to give you an idea, for every one job in fossil fuels, to create one unit of energy, you need 2 or 3 of those jobs in solar power, and the fastest growing opportunities in the next decade are wind technitian and solar technitian. Think about that!

> Interviewer: Benefit the economy, benefit the environment in the same way. We've talked before on the saturday show about the arctic and the Amazon to be the two areas with the biggest change that we're seeing ahead.

> Jeff: So these *are tipping points*, we need to watch them closely. The Amazon is being slashed and burned very quickly, climate change is drying it out, and if we're not careful, it could turn into a savannah. So, from a rain forest, with all that life into a savannah. Right now, it's acting as a carbon sink, it's pulling tons of carbon out of the atmosphere, it is *helping* us slow down the consequences of climate change, and pretty soon it may not be able to do that. Same thing with the arctic and permafrost. Permafrost is frozen ground in the arctic tundra, that has now *this year* changed from being a net *abosrber* of carbon dioxide to being a net *emmitter*, which means that it causes climate change to spiral, and go even faster. And, we have to watch for destabilization of ice shelves in the arctic and anarctic, that's something we hope doesn't happen, but if it does, sea level creeps up even faster.

housing.comment:
> Enphase and other microinverters will not work as well for a AC coupled system.

This specific line is 100% factually incorrect. Here's an article refuting you: https://www.civicsolar.com/article/ac-coupling-microinverters

We install at least 1 or 2 PowerWall systems with microinverters every week. In terms of how electricity works, there is literally zero difference between using modern microinverters, string inverters, or string+optimizers with AC-coupled batteries as long as the inverter supports a technology like frequency shifting to disable the solar once the battery's approaching full charge. The entire industry is shifting away from DC-coupled to AC-coupled systems, with the exception of off-grid setups. If you're on the grid, AC-coupled is almost definitely the way to go.

housing.comment:
Couple things:

1. As solar installer, we would recommend an upgrade as well. Panel is old, full and dont really have the space to add breakers. 

2. Depending on the size of the inverter and the actual rating of the main/bus on a 125A service the max I would be able to add is 25A without derating the main. I dont believe we would be able to derate the main at 100A with current loads. 

3. If youre going to upgrade panels, SCE will do a site visit to review current panel before issuing your disconnect/reconnect. Here is where it gets tricky: depending on your current installation (Overhead OH, Underground UG) there can be some additional costs not included in that 2500: 

3a: If UG, you can be direct burial (no conduit) which would require a trench, lay conduit and SCE typically covers the wiring as part of maintenance (since the wire was likely to fail at some point). Big expense to trench 36" and conduit. If its not direct burial, typically when you upgrade 125/150 to 200 the conduit will not be rated for the new wire size, requiring to trench/upgrade conduit. 

3b. You can use a 125Amain 225Abus rated panel that is solar ready. Would allow for more Amps to be backfed and likely avoid having to trench/upgrade conduit. Wouldn't give you a lot of room to expand, but would save a lot of headaches. 

4. 2500 is not that expensive, typically we are in the 2000-2500 range. Permits, labor, materials all have gone up in price. 

If you do decide to go the higher A route, let us know what you run into. Good luck!

housing.comment:
Nuclear power *was* the fastest way we could have displaced fossil fuel use 15 years ago. Now renewable power is mature and much cheaper, and we are worse at building nuclear plants than we were then.

Yes, we don't presently have necessary battery storage - but that's because we don't really need it. The reason storage is expensive is not because it's intrinsically expensive, it's because there's just not a huge market for storage. As renewables become a significant share of power generation you will start to see storage costs come down.

Of course, what moved the needle on solar and wind was mostly Chinese subsidies - if the US and Europe heavily subsidized the construction of hydrogen electrolysis, flow batteries, and lithium batteries I am confident nuclear would be proven obsolete within 5 years. It seems plausible it will happen anyway (even with the meager subsidies.)

I think around 2030 if prices haven't come down we might need to give up on that route and start investing seriously in nuclear power again but right now I think we should invest in storage, it is most likely going to be the future. (I don't know which techs, it probably won't be lithium ion but who knows.)

housing.comment:
Installing solar is more like buying bonds than stocks. It's not a perfect analogy, but:

1. Guaranteed rate of return. It will never crash like the stock market.
2. The return is inflation adjusted because YOU don't pay higher future rates.
3. When you sell your house, you recover the initial investment (actually, probably a bit  more). This is like the maturity date of a bond.

There are some caveats: If you have 100% net metering, that may, unfortunately, change. The solar install cost recovery will fluctuate with the real estate market, but should still be value added.

I'm making about 7% on my solar investment now, and it sure beats stocks this year!

housing.comment:
If you can look into solar do it.  You are literally giving away money to PG&E that could help to pay for solar panels.  I wouldn't say doing that is for everyone with NEM 3.0 but because you are charging  your vehicle it makes sense.  To cut down on the cost of solar installs you can buy your solar panels and inverter(s) up front instead of through a solar installer and this can save you big money. 

You can buy an [REC 365W solar panel for $250.65](https://a1solarstore.com/r/3938899f1ba425a8a81471bd1aaa8edc) and for microinverters, these [Enphase Ensemble IQ8 Plus are $191.58](https://a1solarstore.com/r/310c7f65a6ac11784d6b09c74b57b1e7).  With NEM 3.0 it is a good plan to look at batteries to sell excess power back to PG&E so these [batteries](https://a1solarstore.com/r/f277401010a2c813b67f95fd45f97c14) might be worth looking at.  With an EV or PHEV you will use up a lot of the power the panels make so batteries aren't necessary. Using the power created from the panels is the best way to use excess power as the rates from PG&E aren't good. All the above parts don't take the 30% solar tax credit into account either.  

If this interests you and you want to start putting a system together, below are a few resources.

[PVWatts calculator](https://pvwatts.nrel.gov/pvwatts.php)

[Google's Project Sunroof](https://sunroof.withgoogle.com/)

[Homeowners Guide to the Solar Tax Credit](https://www.energy.gov/eere/solar/homeowners-guide-federal-tax-credit-solar-photovoltaics)

housing.comment:
And solar power generation, mass scale battery production and charging infrastructure have some pretty good synergies.

Running some ballpark numbers, 2024 solar LCOE is estimated at 100 /MWh. A charger with 0.5 MWh/d utilization and 100 k installation cost amortizes to 50/MWh. If you can get LFP batteries at 100 /kWh and short cycle them for 5k cycles, that ends up at 10 /MWh cost. Add in operating costs and taxes, lets say the end result is 250 /MWh = 0.25 /kWh of costs. That allows for some pretty healthy margins already today. And the costs are only coming down.

Vehicle lifecycle energy usage is 50-100 MWh. A majority of that is going to be home charging, but the total margin on energy sales per vehicle not totally dissimilar to vehicle sales margins.

housing.comment:
How do you think you will get democratic consent, in what passes for democratic system, without widespread pressure from people?

The governments of developed nations are mostly captured by corporate power. That includes big ag - an especially powerful lobby for its size because unfortunately people have staggeringly misguided attitudes towards the agricultural industry.

We don't have to convince everyone in any case. [Research](https://www.science.org/doi/abs/10.1126/science.aas8827) on social change demonstrates that you need about 25% of the population to change their behaviour and the bulk of the rest of society will then follow suit. Remember, while there are of course conservatives and reactionaries out there, most people are constantly trying to keep up with a changing society. Humans are constantly tracking the changes going on around them so they stay in concert with the people in their communities. So if there is a strong current of people changing diet for all the various reasons that they do, then most other people will see that as they way things are now and adapt accordingly. 

Think of social changes like attitudes to gays. One day gay marriage was illegal and lots of people were fine with that. The next day, it was legal and that was celebrated by a decent chunk of the population. Then many of those people originally skeptical quite quickly found themselves not actually bothered any more and actually in favour of the change.

It's not a perfect analogy but it makes my point. People will change their attitudes remarkably quickly when they see a process of shifting attitudes around them.

So that's the point on why it matters at a personal level. We have to lead that change, by our professed attitudes and our example. It does matter and it can make a difference, both at a small scale and at a large scale.

If you are waiting for the government to tell you what to eat, you'll be waiting an eternity. The government can't even tell people not to use horribly dangerous and polluting vehicles. It can't tell the oil and gas industry that its days exploring for new oil and gas are over. It can't tell people not to install gas boilers. It can't tell builders to build efficient homes with solar panels. You think any plausible government is going to tell people they can't eat beef? It will NEVER happen. But that's OK - it doesn't need to. We can choose not to. Right now.

My panels took just over 2 years to pay for themselves.

housing.comment:
The kwh rate matters the most for people looking to finance their system. At 13 cents per kwh, the numbers on financing solar are not that good. On cash, the numbers may not be that bad. Let's assume you live in an area with favorable net metering laws (you get paid nicely for excess power produced):

He paid $8400 after tax credits for his system

The system should produced between 4500kwh - 5000kwh annually.

This equates to \~$620 in electricity costs per year. 

$8400 / $620 = 13.5 years to get his money back at 0% inflation and \~20 years. That would be an almost guaranteed 7.4% annual return on his money.

If you use a modest 4% rate increase per year by the electric company, then the breakeven would be closer to 10 years (10% annual return on money), and the panels should last 30+ years on his home.

The Solar numbers may not be great for mass adoption with only 7.4%-10% annual return and bad financing numbers, but it still does make some sort of financial sense.

food.comment:
>From where does the moral evaluation derive if not suffering (which is a result of sentience)?

It indeed derives from sentience and suffering. That doesn't mean that the resulting moral imperative is to diminish suffering. For example, I don't think killing an animal in a way that causes no suffering would be justifiable.

>If you didn't believe it mattered whether or not you exploited animals on an individual level, why bother acting on your belief?

I read that as equivalent to "If you don't believe something, why act on that belief?". Did I get that wrong? Why should one feel compelled to act on a belief they don't hold?

>You're an abolitionist of one, because it's the right thing to do.

I think it is right yes. There's a major difference in stopping (as far as is possible and practical) one's contribution to an undesirable situation and diminishing one's contribution.

>This makes my point.

What point was that? The one about "either you allow that individually reducing suffering through your veganism is ethical and valid, or you are living a lie"? I have already pointed out that I don't see it as a matter of reducing suffering.

food.comment:
If you have the time for it in your school schedule (and your school offers it) I'd highly recommend taking a nutrition class. The health benefits of a vegan diet are massive, from lowering your risk of several chronic diseases like cardiovascular disease and diabetes to reducing the amount of preservatives, chemicals, and other icky things that you put in your body. 

A vegan diet really isn't that hard to do "correctly." The only thing in flesh that isn't in plants is vitamin B12, and all fortified foods (think rice, flour, bread, etc.) have b12. If you're really worried about it you and take supplements, but I have found that it isn't necessary (as have all my veggie friends). Protein isn't the issue that most people think it is. You need 0.8 grams of protein for every kilogram you weigh per day (roughly, of course), so 0.8 gram for every 2.2 lbs. Divide your weight by 2.2 and multiply by 0.8. It isn't hard to get that much in a day, you'll find that you easily get more than that. No vegans I know even bother to count their protein in a day, generally if you're getting enough calories you're getting enough protein. 

Remember that our bodies are better equipped for a vegan diet. Eating vegan is healthy, not dangerous. Just be smart about it. Potato chips and candy aren't going to be healthy for you to live off of, obviously. Be adventurous with your veggies, learn to love quinoa (and what's not to love?!?!), breathe deep, and relax. 

Feel free to PM me if you need any advice or anything. I don't have a book to recommend you, sadly, but I doubt you really need one. Good luck!

Yes, but isn't that problem way worse with other pollinating insects? It also bothers me that nobody asks about the farming practices of plants in general. Insects are killed by very large numbers as a routine in farming, yet some vegans keep going on and on about how unethical honey is. I believe that honey production kills way less insects than the production of plant-based sugars. 
On that you could argue that some bees are fed plant-based sugars as substitutes for honey, I don't know how common this is, but I know that in Germany, organic honey has to be produced without feeding the bees substitute sugars, so it is very much possible.

food.comment:
The ultimate disrespect is the torture and killing of that animal for our own purposes. Eating or wearing that animal, whether or not it would have been "thrown away", only adds to the disrespect. Vegans should not participate in that. 

When I became a vegan, I did get rid of all my leather and wool clothing. Why would I want to wear the product of animal exploitation? The idea that the animal "sacrificed" its skin for me doesn't make sense. The skin was ripped away in the process of killing that animal.

In any case, I agree that there is no such thing as a "free vegan". People can call their lifestyles whatever they wish, but as soon as you eat animal products you are disqualified as a vegan by definition.

food.comment:
Caring about people and caring about animals are not mutually exclusive. Just because you are a vegan does not necessarily mean that you care about animals more than people, either. I care about both, and I'm sure most other vegans do, too.

I am a member of a local CSA (community-supported agriculture), which provides me with a share of the fruits and vegetables grown by a local farm each week. [Look around a bit](http://www.localharvest.org/), if you are concerned about this issue. You might not *have* to shop at those places.

Additionally, the humans who work in slaughterhouses and meat packing facilities [suffer injuries, abuse, and exploitation](http://www.motherjones.com/politics/2001/07/dangerous-meatpacking-jobs-eric-schlosser). So, by not eating meat, you don't support the companies that are committing abuses against both humans and animals.

Protein deficiency is hardly an issue- even if you don't eat tofu or beans, you're getting enough protein to be healthy. If vegan options aren't provided for a kid (and I wouldn't expect any parent to start cooking vegan food for their child), getting a job and doing one's own grocery shopping is an option.

Really, moving out doesn't solve anything- getting a job does. You can't move out without a source of income in the first place. Until the kid can provide for itself (ex. if it's underage and can't get a job off the books, or it just can't get hired), it's the parents' responsibility to take care of it.

food.comment:
Dude, I'm going to try to help you out. 

She didn't post this image asking for critiques of her body. She posted it to proudly share her method of activism and to ask about others' forms of activism. 

But let's say this post wasn't about vegan activism. Let's say it was just a post with an image of her body, no caption. Would it have been okay to tell her that she lives up to your personal sexual preferences then?

It is one thing to look at a bodybuilder in the context of bodybuilding. It is one thing to make encouraging comments about a bodybuilder's technique or dedication or hard work. It's fine to offer suggestions and advice *when it is requested*. It's fine to offer *objective* critiques *when requested*. 

It is another thing entirely to make comments about your opinion and preferences regarding the "femininity" of a bodybuilder. When you say things like that, you're no longer talking about her as a person or a bodybuilder, you're objectifying her as a woman subject to your sexual preferences (which don't matter to her or anyone else). 

In this case, you may think you were giving her a compliment, but most of us just see you ignoring the point of the post, zoning in on the fact that she is a sex object that lives up to your standards, and disparaging women who choose to look muscular. It's just rude, not to mention sexist. Women are free to become as muscular as they like, and in this world, we need fewer of men's never-ending, contradictory, no-win opinions about our bodies.

food.comment:
I thought this would be a simple one, since iodine deficiency is incredibly common in vegans vs. the general population, and Ive seen country-specific sources recommending supplementation. Finding info in English? Thats where it seems to get difficult, but Ill get back to finding out a good general source for this. PubMed gives out a good amount of results regarding iodine deficiency itself.

My educated guess would be that it depends a lot on the amount of iodine in table salt, if iodized salt is used in food production, and how much of the diet is made up of products with salt already added. If salt used in food manufacturing is also iodized or a person barely consumes anything with it added, Im guessing that adding in salt with a high enough level of iodine would be sufficient. 

Ive personally just stuck to figuring out what my intake of iodine generally is. Im on the low side, especially since my intake of any seaweeds is low.

food.comment:
I agree with that.  Everybody should be upfront when they're discussing their different reasons for being vegan.  It's our responsibility not to be misleading.  

I think that in order to appeal to a larger group of people that it's good to cover all of the different bases.  And even if people don't end up being fully vegan, or vegan for the right reasons, it's still better than nothing.  And maybe people who are attracted by health benefits or disease prevention could start for those reasons, but stay for ethical reasons as they become more informed and realize that a vegan diet isn't hard to stick to.  

It's a softer approach for sure.  Some people just completely block you out when you start talking about cruelty and slavery, but they'll listen to stuff about health.  It gets your foot in the door, at least.  A lot of people won't listen to somebody they consider a militant vegan.  

But yeah, I definitely get what you're saying.  I guess the words hate and real threw me off.  At the end of the day it's for the animals.  But it isn't one dimensional.  I'm a vegan for lots of reasons, and saving animals is the most important one, but not the only one.

food.comment:
Veganism is first and foremost an animal rights movement, not a health diet. 

That said, as someone who struggled with cancer, several hormonal and immune system conditions being vegan (and especially following a *healthy* vegan diet - not a junkfood one) improved a lot of symptoms for me. I do feel more active. Fatigue from thyroid conditions was reducing. My skin got better. It was easier to maintain weight. My chronically high cholesterol is on normal levels again. Even my chronic hormonal migraines are occluding less frequently.

food.comment: I guess I could have come off as rude if she thought it was sarcasm. As far as that's concerned though, I feel no need to apologize because I said "honey isn't vegan and neither is powdered sugar :)" and she went full on crazy. I mean it looked delicious until I saw that. It wasn't intended to be rude at all but yet I got called an idiot?? I understand that different vegans have stricter rules than others, but to completely deny that honey isn't vegan? I don't eat honey, but I do eat sugar. Sadly, none of those are vegan unless it's bone char free sugar. Oh well, but I don't think someone who goes full on crazy like that should be in a supportive subreddit about being vegan. :p
